Trial_Design.evidence: The study was designed as a RCT with two arms (intervention and control).

Participants.evidence: A total of 40 patients with colorectal cancer (WHO performance status I or II) undergoing elective surgery with curative intent were included.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention consisted of 4 weeks of multimodal prehabilitation, with supervised physical training, nutritional support and medical optimization. The control group received standard of care.

Objective.evidence: The aim of the present study was to test the effect of prehabilitation on immediate postoperative recovery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was postoperative recovery within the first 3 postoperative days, measured by Quality of Recovery-15, a validated questionnaire with a scoring range between 0 and 150 and a minimal clinically relevant difference of 8.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 40 patients with colorectal cancer (WHO performance status I or II) undergoing elective surgery with curative intent were included.

Number_Analysed.evidence: In total, 36 patients were analysed with 16 in the intervention group and 20 in the control group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The overall treatment effect associated with the intervention was a 21.9 (95% c.i. 4.5–39.3) higher quality of recovery-15 score during the first 3 postoperative days compared to control, well above the minimal clinically relevant difference.
